qas.question: What's the process whereby metal filaments are grown on or in a PCB via DC voltage?
Along with silver and aluminum, what metal grows metal filaments when exposed to an electric field?
In addition to "whiskers," what does silver sprout around ions like halide?
What do scientist call the function whereby tin changes when it's very cold?
What's present in plated surfaces that causes tin to grow metal filaments?
What material is a good choice for electronics use?
Tin plast is what type of issue?
The transformation of silver to a powdery allotrope at low temperature is know as what?
AC voltage bias helps promote the growth of what?

context: <a0_0>Electrochemical migration<a0_0/> (ECM) is the growth of <b8_0>conductive metal filaments<b8_0/> on or in a printed circuit board (PCB) under the influence of a DC voltage bias. Silver, <a1_0>zinc<a1_0/>, and aluminum are known to grow whiskers under the influence of an electric field. <b5_0>Silver<b5_0/> also grows <a2_0>conducting surface paths<a2_0/> in the presence of halide and other ions, making it a poor choice for electronics use. Tin will grow "whiskers" due to <a4_0>tension<a4_0/> in the plated surface. Tin-Lead or solder plating also grows whiskers, only reduced by the percentage Tin replaced. Reflow to melt solder or tin plate to relieve surface stress lowers whisker incidence. Another <b6_0>coating<b6_0/> issue is <a3_0><b7_0>tin pest<b7_0/><a3_0/>, the transformation of tin to a powdery allotrope at low temperature.
